answers.answer: I don't have personal experience but there are many women who have had vbac's, even home birth vbac's so definitely explore your options! Talk to a midwife for advice if you can!

Im attempting a vbac with this pregnancy. Im 38weeks. There is only a less than 1percent chance of a uterine rupture during a vbac. There are more risks associated with a normal c section than a vbac is what i was told. Vbac success rate depends on why you had a section in the first place. I never went into labor with my first. I had him by emergency section at 35weeks due to preeclampsia so Im a great candidate. I can't get pitocin though since the rupture rate goes up and Im opting out of getting an epi because of the chance it slows or stops my labor.

That's the same reason I had to have a c-section.  They found out I had preeclampsia a few days before i had my 1st baby, but i didn't have to have a c-section right off, they induced me. I had to end up having a c-section b/c I was induced on that Monday, was in labor from Monday-Wednesday and only dilated to 4cm. His heart rate started to drop so they decided to take him

question: Hello everyone, my husband and I just found out yesterday that we're expecting baby #2. I had a c-section with my 1st baby and was wondering if I would have to have another c-section.  After delivering my first child,  the Dr told me that I could have a VBAC if we ever decided to have another one. I would like to have a VBAC but I was told that it's very risky. Can anyone relate?
title: Another c-section
